author: Julia Strammer
title: Arbeitslosigkeit in Kärnten rückläufig - Herausforderungen bleiben
text:
Kärnten präsentiert sich im Bundesländervergleich bei den Arbeitslosenzahlen weiterhin gut aufgestellt. Während die Arbeitslosenquote im Juni 2019 noch bei 6,5 Prozent lag und während der Corona-Pandemie 2020 auf 10 Prozent stieg, beträgt sie im Juni 2025 mit 5,8 Prozent wieder weniger als vor der Krise.
Gute Zusammenarbeit zwischen Land, AMS und Sozialpartnern Landeshauptmann Peter Kaiser (SPÖ) und LH-Stellvertreterin Gaby Schaunig (SPÖ) führen diesen Erfolg auf die bewährte Zusammenarbeit von Land, AMS und Sozialpartnern sowie die gezielten Maßnahmen im Rahmen des Territorialen Beschäftigungspaktes zurück. Dieser ermöglicht es, passgenaue Programme für unterschiedliche Zielgruppen anzubieten – von Jugendlichen bis hin zu älteren Arbeitnehmern.
©LPD Kärnten/Jannach Landeshauptmann Peter Kaiser (SPÖ) freut sich über die positive Entwicklung des Arbeitsmarktes. ©LPD Kärnten/Wajand LH-Stellvertreterin Gaby Schaunig (SPÖ) blickt positiv auf den Kärntner Arbeitsmarkt. Positive Entwicklungen in der Bauwirtschaft „Kärnten zeigt, dass wirtschaftliche Stabilität, soziale Sicherheit und Zukunftschancen Hand in Hand gehen können“, so Kaiser. Investitionen in Weiterbildung, Digitalisierung und nachhaltige Branchen stärken den Arbeitsmarkt und verbessern zugleich die Qualität der Arbeitsplätze. Besonders erfreulich sind die Entwicklungen in der Bauwirtschaft, die durch gezielte Infrastrukturmaßnahmen weiter gefördert wird und zusätzliche Beschäftigung schafft.
Gerhard Köfer mahnt zur Vorsicht Team Kärnten-Chef Gerhard Köfer mahnt jedoch zur Vorsicht: Trotz der positiven Zahlen steht Kärnten vor Herausforderungen wie Überalterung, Abwanderung und Fachkräftemangel, vor allem in technischen Berufen und der Gastronomie. Er fordert eine gründliche Überprüfung aller arbeitsmarktpolitischen Maßnahmen und eine engere Zusammenarbeit zwischen Bildungseinrichtungen und Unternehmen, um den Anforderungen des Arbeitsmarktes besser gerecht zu werden.
©zVg. Team Kärnten-Chef Gerhard Köfer mahnt zur Vorsicht.

author: Redacción El Comercio Perú
title: Autoridades de turismo de Perú, Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia y CAN presentan "Caminos Andinos"
text:
Saber más
En el marco de la Feria Internacional de Turismo (FITUR), las autoridades de turismo de Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador y el Perú y la Secretaría General de la Comunidad Andina (CAN) anunciaron el próximo lanzamiento de “Caminos Andinos”.
Se trata de una iniciativa que busca reforzar el posicionamiento de los países andinos como una región turística, que cuenta con una oferta diversificada y descentralizada, compuesta por rutas, que además de conectar destinos maduros y convencionales, también promueve la visita a destinos poco conocidos, lo cual generará un impacto positivo en las comunidades locales.
LEE TAMBIÉN:[MEF aprueba ley que regula contrataciones de bienes,, servicios y obras de las entidades públicas]
El secretario general de la Comunidad Andina, embajador Gonzalo Gutiérrez, remarcó que este proyecto se viene trabajando de manera conjunta entre los países desde el 2022, como una herramienta para recuperar la industria turística de la región andina, que fue afectada por la emergencia sanitaria del COVID-19.
“Estamos convencidos de que podemos tener una mayor participación en el turismo internacional. Por ello, guiados por el espíritu integrador, trabajamos en una oferta consolidada de nuestros atractivos turísticos que se pueda presentar a la comunidad internacional a través de una plataforma digital”, detalló el Secretario General de la CAN.
Por su parte, Alberto Lora, director general de Transformación Productiva, Integración Física y Servicios de la Secretaría General de la Comunidad Andina, explicó que “Caminos Andinos” brindará información detallada sobre las rutas a lo largo de los países andinos y ofrecerá recomendaciones útiles sobre clima, transporte, moneda, cultura, gastronomía y costumbres, facilitando así la planificación de viajes.
MÁS INFORMACIÓN:[¿Los colegios privados pueden incrementar las pensiones de los alumnos?]
Cabe precisar que el turismo, que en 2024 representó un promedio del 2% del PIB en cada país andino, se ha convertido en un sector prioritario para el desarrollo de estos territorios. De esa manera, en el mismo año, el sector generó aproximadamente 3.8 millones de plazas de empleo en la región y recibió a 11.6 millones de visitantes no residentes.
Los principales países emisores de visitantes a la Comunidad Andina son Estados Unidos, Canadá y México. En Europa destacan España, Francia, Alemania, Italia y Reino Unido. En el contexto suramericano, Chile, Argentina y Brasil se posicionan como mercados emisores clave. “Caminos Andinos” permitirá ofrecer a los turistas una experiencia única y auténtica que destaque la riqueza cultural y natural en los destinos de la costa, la sierra y la amazonía que ofrece la región andina en conjunto.

title: BAT Vietnam implements third consecutive year of afforestation projects with Gaia - VnExpress International
text: Both organizations have completed their afforestation project for the 2022-2024 period, achieving the goal of facilitating the conversion of 120 hectares of mudflats into mangrove forest in Ca Mau Cape National Park while covering 4 hectares in Dong Nai Culture and Nature Reserve. BAT Vietnam and Gaia jointly organized ESG Day 2024 in Ca Mau Cape National Park. Photo courtesy of Gaia | The importance of forests to the environment and human life is undeniable. According to i-Tree, a software developed by the U.S. Forest Service for assessing and managing forests, afforestation removes approximately 31.6 million tons of carbon, absorbs about 372 million kilograms of air pollution, and prevents 5,530 million gallons of stormwater runoff. McKinsey & Company further emphasizes that afforestation is a critical solution for carbon sequestration, significantly supporting Vietnam's commitment to achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. In Vietnam, saltwater intrusion in the Mekong Delta has become increasingly severe, with many provinces experiencing a decline in seasonal water levels, loss of alluvium, and diminishing aquaculture resources. The situation is exacerbating soil degradation and threatening the region's biodiversity. According to the Meteorological and Hydrological Administration, Vietnam is among the six countries most severely affected by climate change. By 2100, nearly 40% of the Mekong Delta could be submerged. Regenerating mangrove forests is thus crucial for combating saltwater intrusion, sequestering carbon, and preserving biodiversity. Studies show that mangrove forests can sequester 4 to 10 times more carbon than terrestrial forests and play a vital role in bridging marine and terrestrial ecosystems, offering an ideal habitat for a diverse range of species. This underscores BAT Vietnam's initiative to regenerate and conserve mangrove forests in Ca Mau Cape National Park from 2022 to 2024. Numerous mangrove saplings have emerged in areas regenerated by BAT Vietnam in 2022. Photo courtesy of Gaia | Through this afforestation project, launched in 2022 in partnership with Gaia, BAT Vietnam reaffirms its commitment to two key sustainability priorities: biodiversity conservation and climate change mitigation. "BAT Vietnam acknowledges that, in addition to our internal efforts to address climate change within our value chain, we must collaborate with the government, agencies, organizations, and other stakeholders to restore degraded forests and protect biodiversity," said Do Hoang Anh, Head of Corporate and Regulatory Affairs at BAT Vietnam Cluster. In 2024, BAT Vietnam continues working with Gaia to convert 40 hectares of mudflats into mangrove forests in Ca Mau Cape National Park. To mark the start of this year's project, BAT Vietnam hosted the ESG Day with 50 employees, who contributed hundreds of volunteer hours. Employees and volunteers from Gaia, along with officers from the Ca Mau Cape National Park Management Board, helped build fences and install nets to protect areas earmarked for mangrove growth. This marks the third consecutive year of BAT Vietnam's ESG Day, featuring afforestation activities in Ca Mau Cape. BAT Vietnam and Gaia are regenerating 40 hectares of mudflats into forests in Ca Mau Cape National Park. Photo courtesy of Gaia | Jahid Shafique, Head of Human Resources, Culture, and Inclusion at BAT Vietnam, emphasized the broader significance of this initiative. "BAT Vietnam's afforestation project with Gaia is not just an environmental effort; it also reflects our core value of ‘Do the Right Thing' by prioritizing sustainability and environmental responsibility." "The zoning, regeneration activities, and knowledge gained about mangrove forests during ESG Day not only deepen our team's understanding of environmental protection but also foster internal solidarity, strengthening the company's sense of responsibility," he added. BAT Vietnam's afforestation project fosters solidarity and responsibility among team members. Photo courtesy of Gaia | In 2022 and 2023, BAT Vietnam and Gaia successfully regenerated 80 hectares of mudflats into forest in Ca Mau Cape National Park and planted 4 hectares of forest in Dong Nai Culture and Nature Reserve. Over the three years of the program, a total of 124 hectares have been afforested in these regions. Both organizations will continue to monitor and maintain these areas in the coming years to ensure a high survival rate for the newly growing mangroves. Reports indicate that the areas regenerated in 2022 and 2023 have seen a significant number of mangrove saplings emerging. These saplings will be nurtured to grow into healthy, mature mangrove forests in Ca Mau Cape in the coming years. Do Thi Thanh Huyen, Founder and General Director of Gaia Nature Conservation, acknowledged the challenges of reforestation, stating: "Regenerating and caring for forests is a challenging journey. We are deeply grateful for companies like BAT Vietnam, who demonstrate vision and commitment by partnering with us to build ecologically valuable forests." "These forests protect water resources, mitigate the damage caused by typhoons and floods, combat climate change, and provide habitats for numerous species, contributing to Vietnam's 1 billion trees initiative by 2025," she added.

author: time news
title: Apple has been ordered by the EU to end some geo-blocking practices
text:
Apple is once again hauled out by the European Commission. This time, the Cupertino company has received orders to put‍ an end ⁣to its geoblocking practices on European territory. For the EC and national consumer protection authorities, many of these practices are “potentially prohibited” and concern numerous services, including the ‍App Store, Apple Arcade, Apple Music,⁣ iTunes Store, Apple Books and Apple Podcasts. The EU gives the tech giant ⁣one month to lift⁣ these restrictions.
The Commission’s request⁤ concludes a “coordinated” investigation by the Consumer Protection Cooperation (CPC) network, which brings together the national consumer protection authorities of ‍the 27 Member⁢ States as well as those ⁢of Norway and Iceland. In its conclusion, the network notified Apple⁢ yesterday,⁣ Wednesday 13 November 2024, of “potentially prohibited” geo-blocking practices on some of the American company’s multimedia services.
The ⁤three EU criticisms of Apple
Geoblocking means the restriction or modification of the offer of services and content offered to users ​based on their geographical positioning. In simpler terms, a French user of ⁢Apple services, for example, cannot access the same applications or‍ consume the same content as ⁢a user of another European nationality.
While geoblocking is not ⁤banned by⁢ the ⁤EU,​ some‌ practices are. And ‍the CPC identified three in Apple, which violate the geo-blocking regulation, adopted in 2018. The EC recalls that this text “prohibits any unjustified discrimination between EU customers based on their nationality, place of residence ⁢or place of establishment when they wish to purchase goods or services from traders located in a different Member State”.
“No company, large or small, should unfairly discriminate against customers based ‌on ⁢their nationality, place of residence or place of business. ​Preventing geo-blocking helps‌ consumers access the goods and services of their ⁣choice across Europe and strengthens the functioning and integrity of our single market,” commented Margrethe Vestager, European Competition Commissioner.
What do we blame Apple for? First ⁢of​ all, it concerns the interfaces of multimedia services which differ between EU countries.⁤ The press release‍ mentions the App Store, Apple Arcade, Apple Music,‍ iTunes Store, Apple Books, and‌ Apple⁣ Podcasts. “In the mobile application of these services,‍ consumers can only access the interface created for the country in ‍which they registered their Apple account and encounter significant difficulties when trying to access ​another interface, which is against the rules of the EU on the ‍fight against geolocation. block”, we explain.
Additionally, users of Apple services are not authorized to use payment methods issued in a country other than the one indicated when creating their account. “When making purchases ⁣on the Apple Media Services app,⁢ consumers are only permitted to use payment methods (such as ‍a credit/debit card)​ issued in the‍ country in which⁤ they registered their Apple Account,” the EC and CPC continue.
The third criticism⁢ leveled at the bitten apple company concerns the restrictions on downloads. Consumers from one EU ‌country cannot ‌access another country’s version or download applications offered there. Gold, he‌ insists According to the EC, “consumers should‌ be able to download applications ⁤offered in another EU/EEA country ‌when they travel to that country or ‍stay there temporarily”.
Apple has one month ⁢to comply
Apple must respond to⁣ the CPC network’s​ findings within a month and “propose commitments on ​how it intends to remedy the observed practices.” The EC warns the American company that “national authorities may take coercive measures to enforce the legislation” if Apple fails to respond.
This summons adds to numerous previous investigations and accusations by the EU, including on the issue of competition.⁤ The latest decision against Apple dates back to two months ago and comes from the Court ​of Justice of the EU (CJEU), which ordered the Cupertino company to reimburse 13 billion euros in unpaid taxes to the Irish state, closing a case that has lasted​ for years.
Regarding the regulation on geoblocking, the EC had already identified Google in 2023,‍ subject to the same criticism for its Google Play Store application store.
What are the implications of the EU’s ​stance on geoblocking for‍ technology⁤ companies​ like ‌Apple? ‍ Interview between Time.news Editor, Alex Reed, and Digital ‌Economy Expert, Dr. Lisa Harmon
Alex Reed: Thank you for joining us today,​ Dr. Harmon. The European Commission has ‌once again⁢ turned its gaze ​toward Apple,⁣ this time regarding their ⁤geoblocking ‍practices. What are your initial thoughts on this latest⁢ development?
Dr. Lisa Harmon: Thank⁣ you, Alex. This situation highlights a significant issue⁢ in the‍ digital marketplace. Geoblocking restricts consumer access ⁢based ⁤on ​geographical location,​ which can lead to unfair discrimination among ‌EU citizens. The Commission’s actions send a clear message: that in a single digital market, consumers should ​not face barriers due to where they live or ⁤happen to be.
Alex Reed: ‌ Exactly. The EC has given Apple ‍a month to dismantle these practices. Can you break down what specific issues ​the Commission identified?
Dr. Lisa Harmon: Certainly. There are three⁣ main criticisms leveled ​at Apple. First, the apps and services differ ⁢significantly between EU countries, which impedes users from accessing the same content. If, ⁢for⁤ instance, a user from France cannot access the same Apple Music library as someone in Germany, it creates‍ a fragmented experience.
Alex Reed: That makes sense. What’s the second issue?
Dr. Lisa ⁤Harmon: The ​second problem relates to payment methods. Apple‌ requires users to only‌ use‌ payment methods from the country in which they registered their account. So,⁢ if ‍you have an Apple‌ account created in Italy, you can’t use a payment​ method‍ from Spain, even if⁣ you’re traveling there. This is a clear barrier to transactions that the EU⁤ finds unjustified.
Alex Reed: Very interesting. And what about the third criticism?
Dr.‍ Lisa Harmon: The third issue revolves ⁣around access to applications. Consumers from ​one EU country are often unable ​to download apps available in another country. For example, if⁣ you’re traveling in another EU nation, ⁣you⁤ may not be able⁢ to download⁢ a local app that ‌could ‌enrich your experience while you’re there. This restriction is contrary to the idea of a unified ‍digital market within the EU.
Alex Reed: Margrethe ⁢Vestager, ⁤the‌ EU’s‍ Competition Commissioner, mentioned that preventing ‌geoblocking ensures ​consumer access and supports the single‌ market. ‍How do ​you see this playing out in the broader context of the ​tech ⁤industry?
Dr. Lisa Harmon: It highlights a pivotal ‌moment ⁣for tech⁤ giants. As digital services become⁤ more integral to everyday⁤ life,‍ companies like Apple ⁢need ‍to ⁢adapt their business models to⁤ comply ⁢with emerging⁤ regulations. This isn’t just about legalities—it’s a matter of fostering trust ‍with consumers.⁣ The backlash against geoblocking ​could spur other companies to reconsider their practices and work towards‍ more equitable access.
Alex Reed: ⁣With the ‌deadline looming, do you anticipate⁢ that Apple will comply, or might they contest these findings?
Dr. Lisa Harmon: I expect Apple ⁤will likely try ‌to negotiate​ or challenge ‌certain aspects, as they have‍ in the past. However, ⁢given the EU’s ‌commitment to creating a digital single market, ⁣I⁢ think it would be unwise for them to ‌ignore⁤ these⁢ requests entirely. ‍The reputation and consumer loyalty matter too much,⁣ especially in a region where data privacy and consumer ⁤rights are highly ‍prioritized.
Alex Reed: Fascinating insights, Dr. Harmon! Before we wrap up, what do you ⁤think ⁣consumers should take away from this situation?
Dr. Lisa​ Harmon: Consumers should be aware of their rights regarding ‍access‌ to ​services across ⁢borders. Additionally, it’s crucial for them to​ advocate⁢ for fair practices that enhance their experiences. This situation is ‌part of ​a larger‍ conversation about digital‌ sovereignty and consumer empowerment.
Alex Reed: ⁢Thank you, Dr. Harmon, ⁢for‍ sharing your expertise with‍ us today. We’ll be keeping a close ⁣eye⁢ on how this situation unfolds in the coming month.
Dr. Lisa Harmon: Thank ‍you for having me, Alex. I look forward ‍to ​the‍ next ​steps in⁣ this ongoing story!

title: Indian town abuzz as divisive temple nears completion | National |
text:
In an Indian town known as a flashpoint for sectarian violence, workers are crafting the final touches on a divisive temple that has come to symbolise the country's rising tide of Hindu nationalism.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi will next month inaugurate Ayodhya's new shrine to Lord Ram on a site where a mosque once stood, before it was torn down by Hindu zealots more than three decades ago.

author: VNExplorer
title: Ocho trabajos de medio tiempo con flexibilidad y buena remuneración
text:
Trabajo
La flexibilidad en el trabajo es una de las cuestiones más valoradas en estos tiempos. Poder cumplir con las tareas desde cualquier parte del mundo o incluso en el horario que uno quiere parece no tener precio, y cada vez más compañías ofrecen esta modalidad.
Por eso, la plataforma de búsqueda de empleo Flex Jobs elaboró un listado con algunas de las mejores oportunidades con flexibilidad y buena remuneración.
1- Abogado corporativo: estos profesionales se encargan del proceso legal en la formación y operación de las empresas. El pago medio es de 65,26 dólares por hora.
(Vea: Las mejores páginas para encontrar trabajo remoto en español, según especialista)
2- Director ejecutivo: como líder de una organización sin fines de lucro, el trabajo se centrará en juntar fondos o coordinar la administración. De media, pagan hasta 85 dólares la hora.
3- Director financiero: este tipo de trabajadores funcionan como un puente entre los sectores de finanzas y el liderazgo de proyectos. El pago medio es de 67, 21 dólares la hora.
4- Gerente de fondos: gestionar todos los aspectos del proceso para reunir fondos y organizar eventos para los donantes son algunas de las tareas a cumplir. De media, se pueden recibir 60,40 dólares por hora.
Trabajo remoto Trabajo remoto. FOTO: iStock
5- Gerente de Recursos Humanos: se encarga de las cuestiones ligadas con los empleados, desde la selección de personal hasta la adjudicación de los beneficios. El pago medio es de 65,67 dólares por hora.
6- Gerente de Mercadeo: se carga de monitorear y armar las campañas de mercadeo online, siempre alineando todo a los objetivos de la compañía. De media, pagan 66,70 dólares por hora.
7- Director médico: se dedica a ejecutar políticas, sistemas y agendas. Además, tiene que gestionar a otros profesionales como físicos y enfermeros. Hay 50,40 dólares de pago medio.
(Vea: Los cinco perfiles de trabajo remoto mejor pagos en el mundo, según ChatGPT)
8- Enfermera: con educación de posgrado, pueden examinar pacientes, diagnosticar enfermedades y prescribir medicamentos. Ofrece un pago medio de 60,53 dólares la hora.
Para más información, se puede visitar el sitio de Flex Jobs, donde hay en total 20 ofertas laborales de este tipo.
